body: The mist-wrapped municipal building loomed large over the group of men huddled together under a ramp from the Brooklyn Bridge. Three men relaxed on chairs by a smoky fire crackling in an oil drum that served both as a fireplace and a grill for sandwiches given to them each night by volunteers who feed the neighborhood's homeless. One of the men,
title: For the Homeless, It's Life Among the Ruins

body: DURING the 1980's, one of the benefits of living in a New York City brownstone or loft-style cooperative or condominium was the comparatively low real estate tax. This was possible because most of these buildings, usually of 10 or fewer units, had been heavily renovated before they were marketed and had the benefit of at least 12 years of
title: Talking: Assessment; Burdens On Small Buildings

body: Here is a sampling of events scheduled this weekend and on Monday in celebration of the New Year: TODAY RICHMONDTOWN RESTORATION, 441 Clarke Avenue, Richmondtown, S.I. Family scenes and life from the 17th to 19th centuries are demonstrated in the re-created Dutch colonial village. Today and tomorrow, noon to 7 P.M. Admission, $4 ($2.50 for
title: Toward the Countdown

body: The mundane and sometimes grim task of keeping New York City going on Christmas fell to an eclectic group of men and women, some of whom kept the holiday in their own way and some of whom did not. Movie theaters were full; precinct houses were staffed; hospitals tended the sick, and public transportation rumbled beneath and through the city. There
title: It's Another Day in the City, But Not Just Another Day

body: Last week was the worst in Bill Casey's 27-year career in the New York City school system. Today, things get worse. Today, Mr. Casey, the superintendent of Community School Board 15 in southeastern Brooklyn, will have to decide how many teachers, school aides, paraprofessionals and other employees in his district will lose their jobs to meet city
title: Painful Task: Meeting Goal To Cut Costs For Schools

title: And There Shall Be Christmas Music for a While

body: For the first time since the Great Depression, apartment rents are dropping in much of New York City. Real-estate professionals say rents have dropped at least 5 percent to 10 percent -- and in some cases as much as 20 percent and more -- in a variety of city neighborhoods during the last three years. Rents on luxury apartments have dipped
title: After Decades of Rises, Rents Sag in Much of New York City

body: Some developers and city planners think they have conceived an ingenious solution to New York City's housing shortage. It is a squat building, about six stories tall, with individual living units arrayed along a central corridor and an elevator connecting the floors and the street. It is called an apartment house. Once the mainstay of New York's
title: Mid-Rise Apartment Houses Making New York Comeback

title: For 'Recycling Cops,' Dragnets Turn Up Bottles and Cans

body: A car stolen by three teen-agers hit four women at a bus stop in Brooklyn yesterday, killing one. They were hit on Seventh Avenue near Third Street in the Park Slope section, the police said. The woman who was killed was Fiona Pachukas, 27 years old, of Brooklyn, the police said. The others, all of Brooklyn and all treated for injuries, were Donna
title: Car Hits 4 Women and 1 Dies

body: Last March we visited the Jewish Home and Hospital for the Aged at 120 West 106th Street to listen to residents, average age 86, debate what college courses they would invite professors to come and teach. A spirited discussion. We dropped by the other day and learned the courses selected had been smashing successes. The French language course ended
title: About New York; Hearing Voices From Long Ago: Benny, Cantor . . .

body: Four years ago, Sister Kathleen Toner opened Samaritan House. Her goal was to show that homeless mothers and children could be given a place to live that was more like a home and cost less than welfare hotels or the big, impersonal and sometimes dangerous shelters run by New York City. Since then, Samaritan House has prospered, evoked some
title: In Small Shelters, Touch Of Home for Homeless

body: A painting by the French artist Maurice Utrillo that was stolen from a Madison Avenue gallery on Tuesday was recovered in a Brooklyn apartment on Friday, the police said. The painting was one of several found at 382A Sixth Avenue in the Park Slope section of Brooklyn, said Sgt. Norris Holloman, a police spokesman. The police did not know whether
title: Man Arrested as Police Find Stolen Painting

body: Paul La Rosa remembers his father reading him comics in The Daily News, an activity that helped him learn to read. "The letters in the balloons over people's heads sort of snapped together one day, and I learned to understand them," he said. "The Daily News has been a thread through my whole life," said the 37-year-old reporter on strike against a
title: About New York; Out On Strike: Fight on the Line, And in His Heart

body: The battle for The Daily News was being fought in the streets yesterday as striking drivers warned newsstands throughout the city not to sell the paper, frequently backing up the warnings with threats of violence or arson, newsstand dealers said. With few newsstands in the city carrying the paper, circulation emerged as the main issue in the
title: Striking Drivers Issue Warnings On Selling The News, Dealers Say

body: There were signs yesterday that management at The Daily News was encountering serious problems producing and distributing the newspaper in the face of a walkout by 2,200 unionized workers that began last week. At the same time, scores of reporters, editors and other white-collar employees of the 71-year-old newspaper announced that they had decided
title: News Having Trouble Getting Paper Out

body: LEAD: One thousand feet above the noisy, crowded, fast-paced world that is street-level New York, the city is transformed into a serene, toylike configuration of buildings, streets, parks and waterways. title: Above It All
